poem:
Title: Homeward Tide

The deeds of the world are a changing tide,
In Xhaaidlagha Gwaayaai where spirits reside.
Where cedar groves whisper ancient lore,
200 islands reclaimed, a homeland restored.

Underneath the dance of the raven's wing,
Forests and seas echo a dignified ring.
Haida Nation, an old song in reprise,
In the twilight glow of Canadian skies.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Canada hands ‘long-overdue’ title over more than 200 islands to Haida Nation For centuries, the Haida people have known that the impenetrable forests and bountiful waters of Xhaaidlagha Gwaayaai – “the islands at the boundary of the world” – were both a life-giving force and their rightful home. Now, after decades of negotiation, the province of British Columbia has come to the same conclusion: the title over more than 200 islands off Canada’s west coast". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
